dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So, I'm a computer science professor, so I spend a lot of time with computers. How would you define a computer for them?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well, a computer is electronic, like a phone but it's a rectangle, and you can type like tick, tick, tick. And you work on it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Nice. Do you know any of the parts that are inside of a computer?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Can I explain a couple of them to you?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So, inside of every computer is some kind of brain and the technical term for that is CPU, or central processing unit. And those are the pieces of hardware that know how to respond to those instructions. Like moving up or down, or left or right, knows how to do math like addition and subtraction. And then there's at least one other type of hardware inside of a computer called memory or RAM, if you've heard of this?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I know of memory because you have to memorize stuff.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly. And computers have even different types of memory. They have what's called RAM, random access memory, which is where your games, where your programs are stored while they're being used. But then it also has a hard drive, or a solid state drive, which is where your data, your high scores, your documents, once you start writing essays and stories in the future.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It stays there.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Stays permanently. So, even if the power goes out, the computer can still remember that information.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It's still there because the computer can't just like delete all of the words itself.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Hopefully not.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Because your fingers could only do that. Like you have to use your finger to delete all of the stuff.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You have to write.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, have you heard of an algorithm before?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yes. Algorithm is a list of instructions to tell people what to do or like a robot what to do.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly. It's just step by step instructions for doing something, for solving a problem, for instance.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, so like if you have a bedtime routine, then at first you say, I get dressed, I brush my teeth, I read a little story, and then I go to bed.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: All right. Well how about another algorithm? Like what do you tend to eat for lunch? Any types of sandwiches you like?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I eat peanut butter.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Let me get some supplies from the cupboard here. So, should we make an algorithm together?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Why don't we do it this way? Why don't we pretend like I'm a computer or maybe I'm a robot, so I only understand your instructions and so I want you to feed me, no pun intended, an algorithm. So, step-by-step instructions for solving this problem. But remember, algorithms, you have to be precise, you have to give...

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: The right instructions.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: The right instructions. Just do it for me. So, step one was what?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Open the bag.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. Opening the bag of bread.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Stop.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Now what?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Grab the bread and put it on the plate.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Grab the bread and put it on the plate.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Take all the bread back and put it back in there.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [laughing] So, that's like an undo command.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Little control Z? Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Take one bread and put it on the plate.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Take the lid off the peanut butter.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, take the lid off the peanut butter.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Put the lid down.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Take the knife.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Take the knife.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Put the blade inside the peanut butter and spread the peanut butter on the bread.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I'm going to take out some peanut butter and I'm going to spread the peanut butter on the bread.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I put a lot of peanut butter on because I love peanut butter.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh, apparently. I thought I was messing with you here...

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No, no it's fine.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But I think you're apparently happy with this.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Put the knife down, and then grab one bread and put it on top of the second bread, sideways.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Sideways.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Like put it flat on.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh, flat ways, okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And now, done. You're done with your sandwich.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Should we take a delicious bite?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yep. Let's take a bite.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, here we go. What would the next step be here?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Clean all this mess up.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [laughing] Clean all this mess up, right. We made an algorithm, step by step instructions for solving some problem. And if you think about now, how we made peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, sometimes we were imprecise and you didn't give me quite enough information to do the algorithm correctly, and that's why I took out so much bread. Precision, being very, very correct with your instructions is so important in the real world because for instance, when you're using the worldwide web and you're searching for something on Google or Bing...

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You want to do the right thing.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So, like if you type in just Google, then you won't find the answer to your question.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Pretty much everything we do in life is an algorithm, even if we don't use that fancy word to describe it. Because you and I are sort of following instructions either that we came up with ourselves or maybe our parents told us how to do these things. And so, those are just algorithms. But when you start using algorithms in computers, that's when you start writing code.
